The "con-artists from the left or right" are an inevitable consequence of elective government in the absence of (genuine) Democracy.

Another economics Nobel laureate who specialised in this field (James Buchanan) described the problem of "adverse selection" of political agents in the following terms:

“[S]uppose that a monopoly right is to be auctioned; whom will we predict to be the highest bidder? Surely we can presume that the person who intends to exploit the monopoly power most fully, the one for whom the expected profit is highest, will be among the highest bidders for the franchise. In the same way, positions of political power will tend to attract those persons who place higher values on the possession of such power. These persons will tend to be the highest bidders in the allocation of political offices. . . . Is there any presumption that political rent seeking will ultimately allocate offices to the ‘best’ persons? Is there not the overwhelming presumption that offices will be secured by those who value power most highly and who seek to use such power of discretion in the furtherance of their personal projects, be these moral or otherwise? Genuine public-interest motivations may exist and may even be widespread, but are these motivations sufficiently passionate to stimulate people to fight for political office, to compete with those whose passions include the desire to wield power over others?” (James Buchanan and Geoffrey Brennan, “The Reason of Rules”.)

I supported Jeb! because not only were his positions aligned mostly with mine, but I thought he could sell them to a Republican Congress. I conditionally support Trump for radically different reasons.

If you look at his stated positions as well as his related pronouncements over the years, other than immigration, they're quite moderate -- clearly, the man has a foot in each ideological camp. I believe he has the potential to pull our congressional ideological extremes, kicking and screaming, to the center, where deals can be made. And I believe he WILL force deals. I don't believe he cares a fig about parties and would seek to define solutions that he could sell to enough Americans to make them real.

God, we need that so desperately.

If you listen to Hillary, she's mouthing leftish platitudes as if she has the slightest chance of getting ANY of them enacted. She's the low-risk candidate, but also the low-return candidate, as well. I prefer the high-risk, high potential return alternative.

Now, of course, Trump may NOT adopt a measure of gravitas or offer a rational policy framework with some meat on it; and if he fails to do so, I can always turn right around and support Hillary as the best of two badly flawed choices, but as the one who would get us into less trouble.

You, on the other hand, are utterly enslaved to party, and will support whoever Democrats tell you to support, irrespective of her chances of actually making better lives for Americans.
